@value.label: General
@value.definition: Details and costs that cannot be charged to any specific function onboard, e.g. general arrangement, quality assurance, launching, dry-docking and guarantee work.

@value.label: Specification, estimating, drawing, instruction, courses
@value.definition: The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated, costs/expenses for items such as the following: - Design and calculations. - Drawing including tracing. - Preparation of specifications, lists, tables, etc. - Purchasing (drawing offices).
references: 448 Nameplates/Marking on Machinery, Equipment, Pipes, Cables
101 Contract/Specification Work, General Design, Model Testing

@id: 101 Contract/Specification Work, General Design, Model Testing

@value.label: Contract/specification work, general design, model testing
@value.definition: Contract and specification work including printing of specifications. Model testing including travels. Design and calculation work after contract is signed, including drawing and calculations connected with: - General arrangements. - Lines and body plans, moulded. - Tonnage tables and stability curves. - Delivery drawings. - Launching calculations, etc. - Stability, inclination and vibration calculations. - Cross curves. - Preparation of sounding tables Drawings including calculation and ordering concerning the ship in general, i.e., drawings, etc. which cover more than one primary group (drawings, etc., which cannot be referred to subgroup 102-106). - Copy work, Log books, Survey books.
references: 108 Purchase/Renting of Drawings, Patents, Licences and Consultation
106 Drawing, Ordering, etc., Machinery Components, Machinery/Ship Systems
105 Drawing, Ordering, etc., Equipment for Crew and Passengers
448 Nameplates/Marking on Machinery, Equipment, Pipes, Cables
107 Estimating, Drawing and Offers, Change Orders

@value.label: Drawing, ordering, etc., hull
@value.definition: Preparation of drawings, steel specifications, calculations etc. and ordering work concerning hull (w.r.t. items included in primary group 2). Programming and/or optical drawing work including work with film and negatives, aluminum plate templates for frame plan, etc. Preparation of half model.
references: 101 Contract/Specification Work, General Design, Model Testing

@id: 103 Drawing, Ordering, etc., Equipment for Cargo

@value.label: Drawing, ordering, etc., equipment for cargo
@value.definition: Preparation of drawings, calculations etc. and ordering work concerning equipment for cargo (w.r.t. machinery, system and equipment in primary group 3).
references: 101 Contract/Specification Work, General Design, Model Testing

@value.label: Drawing, ordering, etc., ship equipment
@value.definition: Preparation of drawings, calculations etc. and ordering work concerning ship equipment (w.r.t. machinery, systems and equipment in primary group 4).
references: 105 Drawing, Ordering, etc., Equipment for Crew and Passengers
101 Contract/Specification Work, General Design, Model Testing

@id: 105 Drawing, Ordering, etc., Equipment for Crew and Passengers

@value.label: Drawing, ordering, etc., equipment for crew and passengers
@value.definition: Preparation of drawings, calculations etc. and ordering work Concerning equipment for crew and passenger (w.r.t. machinery, systems & equipment in primary group 5). Accommodation drawings.
references: 448 Nameplates/Marking on Machinery, Equipment, Pipes, Cables

@id: 106 Drawing, Ordering, etc., Machinery Components, Machinery/Ship Systems

@value.label: Drawing, ordering, etc., machinery components, machinery/ship systems
@value.definition: Preparation of drawings, calculations etc. and ordering work concerning machinery main components and machinery/ship systems (w.r.t. machinery, systems and equipment in primary group 6, 7 and 8). Engine room arrangement. Photographing including work with film and negatives concerning engine room models (Note! see also Ref.).
references: 448 Nameplates/Marking on Machinery, Equipment, Pipes, Cables

@id: 107 Estimating, Drawing and Offers, Change Orders

@value.label: Estimating, drawing and offers, change orders
@value.definition: Preparation of tenders including calculation, estimating and drawing concerning alterations and additional work (according to owner's request).
references: 101 Contract/Specification Work, General Design, Model Testing

@id: 108 Purchase/Renting of Drawings, Patents, Licences and Consultation

@value.label: Purchase/renting of drawings, patents, licences and consultation
@value.definition: Purchase/renting of drawings/calculations. License/patent fees which cannot be referred to machinery or equipment in one subgroup. Fees to consultants for work which cannot be referred to machinery, systems or equipment in one subgroup.
references: 101 Contract/Specification Work, General Design, Model Testing
107 Estimating, Drawing and Offers, Change Orders

@value.label: Maintenance systems, instruction material
@value.definition: Expenses/costs connected with instruction material and courses for crew and owner's representatives. Preparation of main- tenance and spare parts systems for the ship, including forms etc.
references: 448 Nameplates/Marking on Machinery, Equipment, Pipes, Cables

@value.label: Insurance, fees, certificates, representation
@value.definition: The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated, costs/expenses for services rendered by others and other indirect cost- s/expenses which can be referred to the ship. The services are mainly of such a character that they cannot be referred dir- ectly to functions (in subgroups of primary group 2 to 8).

@value.label: General insurance
@value.definition: Insurances which cover the complete ship, machinery and equipment in several groups/subgroups and special insurances including: - Construction risk insurance. - General policies and insurances which cover several categories of equipment. - Trial trip insurances. - Insurance against delayed delivery (delay insurance). - Insurance for coverage of guarantee expenses. - Insurance against devaluation and discount rate loss.
references: 113 Building Advance Interest, Discount, Finance Costs

@id: 112 Classification and Statutory Fees and Certificates

@value.label: Classification and statutory fees and certificates
@value.definition: Fees charged by classification society, maritime authorities and other institutions (Department of health, Ministry of Trans- port etc.), for classification, approvals and registry, issue of letters and certificates (Note! only certificates which cannot be referred to machinery and equipment in one subgroup) e.g.: - Certificates issued by the classification society - Certificates issued by the flag state - Certificates issued by the local Coast Guard. - Certificates related to oil production and storage. On this group included assistance to and all requisitions of  materials/equipment for surveyors of classification societies, authorities etc.
references: 101 Contract/Specification Work, General Design, Model Testing

@id: 113 Building Advance Interest, Discount, Finance Costs

@value.label: Building advance interest, discount, finance costs
@value.definition: Interest on building advances and other general interests. Discount rate losses, losses due to devaluation etc. Costs connected with loans, guarantees and credits.

@value.label: Cancellation expenses
@value.definition: Expenses due to owner's cancellation of contract.

@value.label: Penalties
@value.definition: Penalties suffered by the yard due to late delivery.

@value.label: Broker's commissions
@value.definition: Commissions to brokers for services rendered in connection with contracts for new buildings, re-buildings and/or repairs.
references: 113 Building Advance Interest, Discount, Finance Costs
108 Purchase/Renting of Drawings, Patents, Licences and Consultation

@value.label: Representation, travels, conferences
@value.definition: General representation and travelling (Note! see also Ref.). Conferences and negotiations including refreshments, lodgings etc.
references: 101 Contract/Specification Work, General Design, Model Testing

@value.label: Launching and delivery representation
@value.definition: Representation in connection with launching, tests, trial trips and delivery, including costs/expenses for such as: - Catering. - Entertainment. - Gifts, photographs and film, telegrams. - Lodging, etc. Including also all costs/expenses for trips with the vessel for representation and public relation purposes and/or receptions at for inst. Quay for similar purposes.

@value.label: Unassigned
@value.definition: This code is unassigned and available for use.

@value.label: Quality assurance, general work, models
@value.definition: The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated, general work of administrative and operational character which can be referred to the ship, plus general models. The subgroup includes costs/expenses for work (time consumption) and materials to the extent it may be referred to the ship.

@value.label: Quality assurance, planning, work preparation
@value.definition: Piece work setting, planning (including expenses connected with planning using EDP), work preparation, quality assurance and quality control (QA/QC) and reporting, including preparation of corresponding: - Forms. - Routines. - Statistics etc.

@id: 122 Work Management, Fire Guard, Supervision, Watch Keeping

@value.label: Work management, fire guard, supervision, watch keeping
@value.definition: Fire guard, watch keeping, and other supervision (foreman supervision etc.) which can be referred directly to the ship (on board, at the gangway etc.). Provisional fire extinguishing equipment with installation and removal, including CO2, etc. Here is also included fire fight- ing (and turn-out for fire fighting).

@value.label: Clearing and cleaning
@value.definition: Clearing and cleaning (also for delivery), disinfection and removal of rubbish (from new building) which may be directly referred to the ship, on board, on ways (berths), in dock or possibly other places. Here is also included emptying of tanks on board. (Note! See also Ref.)
references: 143 Crew, Pilots, Tugs, Clearing at Launching
194 Binding and Mending Material, Cleaning Articles
203 Blasting, Shop-Priming, Rolling and Cleaning of Materials

@value.label: Snow clearing, de-icing
@value.definition: Snow clearing and de-icing on board and on ways (berth), drying before welding etc.
references: 136 Provisional Steam, Water, Heating and Ventilation Plants

@value.label: Transportation (excluding hull parts)
@value.definition: Internal transportation, including crane operation of materials and equipment (Note! see also Ref.)
references: 202 Transportation, Sorting and Storage of Hull Materials

@value.label: Assistance with owner's supply
@value.definition: Yard assistance with owner's supply such as: - External transportation. - Unpacking and preparation. - Transportation on board and placing/installation. - Including also direct expenses connected with owner's supplies.

@value.label: Models, albums, photos
@value.definition: Models which cannot be referred to machinery or equipment in one subgroup, such as: - Exhibition model (outfit models) delivered to the owner according to the contract. - Arrangement models (engine room models etc.). - Full scale models (mock-ups). - Albums/photographs, films e.g. to the owner for follow-up during construction (building) period (Note! see also Ref.).
references: 106 Drawing, Ordering, etc., Machinery Components, Machinery/Ship Systems

@value.label: Unassigned
@value.definition: This code is unassigned and available for use.

@value.label: Unassigned
@value.definition: This code is unassigned and available for use.

@value.label: Provisional rigging
@value.definition: The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated, the following costs to the extent they are specific for - or can be referred (spread) to - the respective ship. - Production costs. - Purchases (materials and equipment). - External transportation. - Installation and adjustment, de-mounting (removal) (also of lifting eyes for transportation etc.). - License/patent fees and testing/control connected with the equipment.
references: 564 Shore Gangways with Davits, Landing Booms
52 INTERNAL DECK COVERING, LADDERS, STEPS, RAILING
53 EXT. DECK COVERING, LADDERS, STEPS, FORE AND AFT GANGWAY

@id: 131 Provisional Gangways, Roofs, Hatches, Stairs, Stages for Hull Ext.

@value.label: Provisional gangways, roofs, hatches, stairs, stages for hull ext.
@value.definition: Provisional (temporary) rigging external on hull, including installation, removal and heavy work for stage riggers with such as: - Provisional gangways with gangway signs. - Provisional hatches and access openings in hull. - Provisional stairs and ladders. - Provisional railings and stages (scaffolds). - Provisional roofs etc. - Provisional mooring equipment.

@id: 132 Provisional Roofs, Hatches, Stages for Deck Houses and Superstructure Ext.

@value.label: Provisional roofs, hatches, stages for deck houses and superstructure ext.
@value.definition: Provisional rigging during construction period external on deck houses & superstructure & on open decks, similarly as men- tioned in subgroup 131.
references: 131 Provisional Gangways, Roofs, Hatches, Stairs, Stages for Hull Ext.
134 Provisional Hatches, Ladders, Stages in Engine Room and Accommodation

@id: 133 Provisional Hatches, Ladders, Stages in Cargo Holds/Tanks

@value.label: Provisional hatches, ladders, stages in cargo holds/tanks
@value.definition: Provisional rigging during construction period in/for cargo holds/tanks, similarly as mentioned in subgroup 131.

@id: 134 Provisional Hatches, Ladders, Stages in Engine Room and Accommodation

@value.label: Provisional hatches, ladders, stages in engine room and accommodation
@value.definition: Provisional rigging internal during construction period excluding Cargo holds/tanks, similarly as mentioned in subgroup 131.
references: 131 Provisional Gangways, Roofs, Hatches, Stairs, Stages for Hull Ext.
133 Provisional Hatches, Ladders, Stages in Cargo Holds/Tanks

@value.label: Provisional electric power, lighting, machinery
@value.definition: Provisional arrangement for electric power supply, lighting (electric, paraffin or carbide lamps) and telephones. Including also connections to machines (provisional) such as welding transformers, saws, melting pots, cranes and lifting gear etc. and shifting and mounting of welding transformers. (See also Ref.) Here is also included possible delivery of electric current (according to account) and renting of telephone.
references: 136 Provisional Steam, Water, Heating and Ventilation Plants

@id: 136 Provisional Steam, Water, Heating and Ventilation Plants

@value.label: Provisional steam, water, heating and ventilation plants
@value.definition: Provisional arrangements for supply of water and steam and provisional arrangement for heating and ventilation. Including also heating during tank testing against frost damages, also possible deliveries of water and steam (according to accounts). For repair ships is also included such as provisional arrangement for heating of bottom and sides against frost damages on ship in dry dock or slipway.
references: 122 Work Management, Fire Guard, Supervision, Watch Keeping
142 Launching Arr. with Cradle, Supports, Water Filling, Platform

@id: 137 Provisional Gas, Oxygen and Compressed Air Plants

@value.label: Provisional gas, oxygen and compressed air plants
@value.definition: Provisional arrangement for supply of gas, oxygen and compressed air.

@value.label: Tarpaulin rentals
@value.definition: Rental of tarpaulins in connection with storing, covering, stages etc.
references: 374 Vent./Gas Freeing Systems for Tanks, Wind Sails with Equipment
537 Deck Tables and Chairs, Swimming Pools
316 Protection Plates, Covers, Hatch Tents and Tarpaulins

@value.label: Provisional lifting and transport equipment
@value.definition: Provisional rigging, mounting and demounting, including material consumption involved, of lifting and transport equipment that is used for several purposes, and thus cannot be connected to any particular subgroup, including such as: - Provisional cranes, e.g. building crane onboard. - Provisional personnel lift, e.g. at fitting out quay. - Provisional lifting beams, trolleys and pulleys. - Provisional hydraulic platforms and similar for carrying out sundry work onboard (for example painting, welding, pressure testing, demounting of scaffolding etc.).

@value.label: Work on ways, launching, docking
@value.definition: The subgroups include costs/expenses for work (time consumption) and materials, plus license/patent fees and test- ing/control in connection with the equipment.
references: 122 Work Management, Fire Guard, Supervision, Watch Keeping

@value.label: Keel blocks, pillars, cushions
@value.definition: Support of ship during construction including such as: - Mounting and adjustment of keel blocks. - Support of hull and superstructure/deck houses internal and external, and demounting  and work by berth workers.
references: 142 Launching Arr. with Cradle, Supports, Water Filling, Platform

@id: 142 Launching Arr. with Cradle, Supports, Water Filling, Platform

@value.label: Launching arr. with cradle, supports, water filling, platform
@value.definition: Arrangement and preparation work for launching, including such as: - Sideways transfer of the ship for launching. - Arrangement of cradles and ways. - External and internal supports for launching. - Mounting for launch supports with knees, cradle stoppers, pumps for pushing, buoyancy tanks for launching, etc. - Arrangement of drag chains, wires and brake arrangements. - Removal of dock gate, work with filling of building dock and other preparations. - Securing of rudders, propellers, loose equipment etc. and checking of bottom plugs etc. - Water filling for trimming of hull for launching/de-docking including water consumption. - Arranging of launching platform, masts and flags, buzzer systems, loudspeaker systems, decorations etc. - De-mounting of equipment mentioned above and work by berth workers.
references: 143 Crew, Pilots, Tugs, Clearing at Launching

@id: 143 Crew, Pilots, Tugs, Clearing at Launching

@value.label: Crew, pilots, tugs, clearing at launching
@value.definition: Costs/expenses for crew, pilots and tug boats in connection with launching. Clearing of ways/building dock before and after launching.

@value.label: Dry/slip docking, shipyard project
@value.definition: Costs and expenses for dry docking and slip docking including such as: - Tug boat assistance, diver assistance, harbour pilots. - Support of ship, water filling etc. - Crew on board and on land. - Slip docking and shifting of vessel.

@id: 144020 Shipyard Direct Hire Payroll and Burden

@value.label: Shipyard direct hire payroll and burden

@id: 144022 Shipyard Contract Hire Payroll and Burden

@value.label: Shipyard contract hire payroll and burden
Shifting, towing (excluding launching)
@value.definition: Costs/expenses for shifting hull at the yard and towing hull/hull sections to/from another yard (Note! not in connection with launching and dry docking/slip docking), including such as: - Tug boat assistance, pilots. - Crew on board and on land. - Extra accommodation for tug boat crew, etc.

@value.label: Gas freeing, tank cleaning
@value.definition: Costs/expenses for tank cleaning and gas freeing.

@value.label: Berthing, anchorage
@value.definition: Costs/expenses for berthing and anchorage. - Towboat assistance, diver assistance, harbour pilot. - Personnel on board and ashore. - Shifting of vessel.
references: 143 Crew, Pilots, Tugs, Clearing at Launching

@value.label: Unassigned
@value.definition: This code is unassigned and available for use.

@value.label: Unassigned
@value.definition: This code is unassigned and available for use.

@value.label: Quality control, measurements, tests, trials
@value.definition: The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated, measurements and trials at sea and alongside quay. The subgroups include costs/expenses for work (time consumption) and materials to the extent they can be referred to the ship.
references: 101 Contract/Specification Work, General Design, Model Testing

@value.label: Machinery testing
@value.definition: Costs/expenses during trials and operations, not connected with trial trips, (e.g. at quay) of machinery, equipment, sys- tems, electrical plants etc.(Note! see also Ref.). The subgroup include both scheduled and extra testing and control, including opening of machinery etc. (Note! see also Ref.). Including also extra mooring in connection with such testing.
references: 153 FO and LO for Tests and Trial Trips

@value.label: Capacity, inclination, vibration measurements
@value.definition: Costs/expenses connected with the following measurements: - Capacity measurements. - Inclination measurements (stability measurements). - Vibration measurements, noise measurements. - Measurements during launching. - Measurements for research purposes. Including also renting and freight of instruments in connection with these instruments.
references: 112 Classification and Statutory Fees and Certificates
101 Contract/Specification Work, General Design, Model Testing
205 X-Ray and Ultrasonic Testing of Hull Parts

@id: 153 FO and LO for Tests and Trial Trips

@value.label: Fo and lo for tests and trial trips
@value.definition: Consumption of fuel and lube oil in connection with tests and trial trips, and for boilers, auxiliary engines etc. on board dur- ing construction period. Including also assistance for transportation, reception, bunkering and separation.
references: 142 Launching Arr. with Cradle, Supports, Water Filling, Platform

@value.label: Trial trips
@value.definition: Costs/expenses for trials - trial trips - (technical trials, delivery trials) including such as: - Tug boats and service boats. - Preparations, including smaller corrections/adjustments/completion work. (See also Ref.) - Measurements. - Crew, test engineers and pilots. - Catering for the above.

@value.label: Special tests/trials
@value.definition: Costs/expenses for special tests/trials (testing which are of such unusual character that it cannot be referred to subgroups 151, 152, and/or 154) such as: - Special tests of gas plants at sea, at another yard or plant, with costs/expenses for renting of plant, harbour dues, pur- chase of gas, cost of watch keeping, crew, tug boats, pilots, etc. - Shooting tests and special testing of stabilizer plant, etc., e.g., when the ship is loaded, including items such as men- tioned above.
references: 205 X-Ray and Ultrasonic Testing of Hull Parts

@id: 156 Health, Environment, Safety Drills and Procedures

@value.label: Health, environment, safety drills and procedures
@value.definition: All general work regarding health, environment and safety. Official requirements for internal control related to the ship and contingency plans. - Forms. - Routines. - Procedures.

@id: 171 Disposal of Waste, Garbage, Oil, Chemicals

@value.label: Disposal of waste, garbage, oil, chemicals
@value.definition: Placement of garbage containers and removal of waste, garbage from galley etc, which cannot be referred to an individual repair job. Oil and chemical wastes that have to be removed and destroyed.

@value.label: Crane assistance to ship's  crew
@value.definition: Crane assistance for work that is carried out by the ship's crew.

@value.label: Transport of yard personnel
@value.definition: Transport of personnel who work with ship repair outside the yard.

@value.label: Toilet and wash room outlets
@value.definition: Provisional arr. from toilets and wash rooms to tank in dock. Temporary arr. for toilets during repair or conversion of existing facilities

@value.label: Services to ship's crew (meals, etc.)
@value.definition: Catering of ship's crew. Rental of living quarters, cars, etc, for superintendent, officers, etc.
references: 136 Provisional Steam, Water, Heating and Ventilation Plants

@value.label: Ship mobilization project/owner expenses
@value.definition: Costs/expenses for mobilization of the ship, including direct or in-direct personnel assisting in the mobilization process, freight catering, etc.

@value.label: Office expenses related to shipyard/mobilization/owner expenses
@value.definition: Costs/expenses involving office personnel in the mobilization of the ship, including, travelling expenses from main office to the ship, office equipment and supplies.

@value.definition: The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated, consumption and general used items used during the vessel operation.

@value.label: Accommodation stores
@value.definition: General Consumable items used in the accommodation, such as catering equipment, clothing and linen, cleaning and office supplies, hardware and bathroom equipment

@value.label: Deck department stores
@value.definition: General Consumable items used by the deck department, such as paint and painting equipment, safety and nautical sup- plies and equipment.

@value.label: Consumption articles used during construction
@value.definition: The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated, consumption of materials/equipment during construction period which can- not be charged any particular subgroup.

@value.label: Electrodes
@value.definition: All consumption of electrodes, including welding thread and powder for automatic welding.
references: 194 Binding and Mending Material, Cleaning Articles

@value.label: Gas, oxygen, coal, oil
@value.definition: All consumption of gas and oxygen for the ship including consumption of argon, propane etc. Consumption of coal and oil for hearths, frame ovens etc.
references: 505 Loose Firefighting Apparatuses and Equipment, Firemen's Outfit
122 Work Management, Fire Guard, Supervision, Watch Keeping

@value.label: Tools, jigs
@value.definition: Tools for hull installation such as wedges, set-squares, Installation bolts, lifting eyes, special straps, burner nozzles, etc. which may be referred to the ship. Tools which are damaged/lost (Note! see also Ref.). Jigs (preparation and materials).
references: 44 REPAIR/MAINT./CLEAN. EQUIPMENT WORKSHOP/STORE OUTFIT, NAME PLATES

@id: 194 Binding and Mending Material, Cleaning Articles

@value.label: Binding and mending material, cleaning articles
@value.definition: Consumption of binding and mending materials for the ship such as: - Glue, hemp, pipe putty, soldering metal and material for soldering and gas welding etc. - Steel plastic, wood putty, putty, form wood etc. Consumption of cleaning articles for the ship such as: - Twist, rags, waste, hand paper etc. - Soap, soda, salt ammoniac, lacquer thinners, paraffin etc. - Polishing wax and similar. - Scrubbers, sponges, wash rags, steel wool etc.

@value.label: Equipment for owner's representatives
@value.definition: All requisition of material and equipment for owner's representatives, including such as: - Working clothes and gloves. - Protection equipment. - Flash lights and batteries. - Requisitions etc. Here is included renting of equipment and also laundry and subsistence for repair representatives.
references: 112 Classification and Statutory Fees and Certificates

@value.definition: Requisition of miscellaneous articles of consumption which cannot be referred to subgroup 191 through to and including

@value.label: Hull systems
@value.definition: Hull, superstructure and material protection of the vessel.

@value.label: Hull materials, general hull work
@value.definition: The group includes purchase of hull materials and various general hull work.

@value.label: Hull materials
@value.definition: Purchase and selection of construction materials such as plates, profiles, bars, pipes etc. for primary group 2 which cannot be directly charged. (Note! see also Ref.). Here is also included costs of external transportation and storing of hull mater- ials.
references: 203 Blasting, Shop-Priming, Rolling and Cleaning of Materials

@id: 202 Transportation, Sorting and Storage of Hull Materials

@value.label: Transportation, sorting and storage of hull materials
@value.definition: Discharging, internal transportation including crane operation, sorting, unpacking and storage of all non-prepared steel materials and aluminum materials. Further transportation of hull materials, hull parts and hull sections.

@id: 203 Blasting, Shop-Priming, Rolling and Cleaning of Materials

@value.label: Blasting, shop-priming, rolling and cleaning of materials
@value.definition: Work and material consumption (sand, cleaning ingredient, thinners, primers etc.) in connection with sandblasting shop- priming, straight rolling and possible cleaning of hull materials before preparation.

@value.label: Testing of tanks, bulkheads
@value.definition: Pressure testing of hull tanks and spray testing of bulkheads, decks, doors etc. (or similar, approved tests), including pos- sible repairs/corrections. Here is also included provisional fitting of pipes/hoses for this testing. Also included here are tem- porary arrangements of pipes/hoses etc. for such testing.
references: 136 Provisional Steam, Water, Heating and Ventilation Plants
205 X-Ray and Ultrasonic Testing of Hull Parts

@id: 205 X-Ray and Ultrasonic Testing of Hull Parts

@value.label: X-ray and ultrasonic testing of hull parts
@value.definition: X-ray, ultrasonic and other material testing of hull parts or hull materials and welding tests of materials.

@value.label: Template and mould loft work
@value.definition: Work and material consumption (woodwork etc.) in connection with templates and mould loft work.

@value.label: Joining of hull parts afloat
@value.definition: Additional work and costs on account of joining of hull parts afloat, including such items as: - Additional staging, blending and tightening. - Trimming, positioning/measuring. - Welding of guiding prices, lifting eyes, additional scaffolding, etc. - Fitting of duct with connected equipment. - Welding, adjustments, etc. - Mounting and removal of above mentioned equipment.

@value.label: Unassigned
@value.definition: This code is unassigned and available for use.

@value.label: Unassigned
@value.definition: This code is unassigned and available for use.

@value.label: Afterbody
@value.definition: The afterbody includes: - Stern frame and afterpeak bulkhead. - Upper deck, plus decks, tops and bulkheads below upper deck, aft of the afterpeak bulkhead. - Shell, including shell on poop, aft of the afterpeak bulkhead. - Stern sections with possible parts of decks and bulkheads above upper deck (Note! See also Ref.). - For ships with long superstructure (e.g. passenger ships, car ships etc.), the shell in the afterbody up to the nearest butt of plates above upper deck is included. If the next deck above upper deck is an open deck (not deck house deck), the shell up to this deck is included. The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated: - Production costs. - License and patent fees. - Installation and adjustment. - Welding with chiselling and chamfer burning. - Testing and inspection (in workshops and during installation).

@value.label: Shell panels, separate shell plates
@value.definition: Separate shell plates and shell panels (i.e. shell sections with plates, stiffeners and strengtheners) in the afterbody.
references: 264 Fender and Wear Bars, Ice Fins, Bilge Keels, Air Cushion Arr.
262 Bottom Plugs, Sea Chests, Bilge Wells, Water Jet Intake
267 Gutter Bars, Bulwark, Breakwaters, Gas Barriers

@value.label: First deck with stiffening
@value.definition: Upper deck in the afterbody with stiffeners and strengtheners. Also here are included parts of plate frames, girders, stiffeners, bulk heads, underlying pillars, integrated gutters, ducts etc., which are mounted together with the deck plates or sections.
references: 267 Gutter Bars, Bulwark, Breakwaters, Gas Barriers

@value.label: Unassigned
@value.definition: This code is unassigned and available for use.

@value.label: Stern sections, stern tube bulkheads
@value.definition: Sections in the afterbody apart from the pure shell sections and stern sections, including: - Afterpeak bulkhead (Note! see also Ref.). - Bulkheads, wash-bulkheads and vertical parts for built-in tanks. - Decks and tank tops below upper deck. - Rudder trunk, chain locker with strainer plate, trunk etc. - Parts of poop included in the aft stern section. - Parts of shell and upper deck fixed to the above mentioned deck or bulkheads. Included here are parts of frames, knees, stiffeners, pillars, girders, transverses, floors etc., mounted on the plates, plus parts of integrated gutters and bilge wells.
references: 402 Rudder Carriers, Rudder Stocks, Rudder Bearings
264 Fender and Wear Bars, Ice Fins, Bilge Keels, Air Cushion Arr.

@value.label: Unassigned
@value.definition: This code is unassigned and available for use.

@value.label: Stern frame sections
@value.definition: Stern frame sections with: - Heel piece. - Propeller stern and propeller boss (stern boss). - Stern frame section, rudder stern (rudder horn) (including stern bearing boss), stern bearing. - Stern frame for twin screw vessels. - Parts of shell, after peak bulkheads and stiffeners fastened to the above. - If the stern frame section is made of cast steel, the material costs are to be charged this subgroup.
references: 402 Rudder Carriers, Rudder Stocks, Rudder Bearings

@value.label: Unassigned
@value.definition: This code is unassigned and available for use.

@value.label: Engine area
@value.definition: The engine area includes: - Forward engine room bulkhead and aft engine room bulkhead when this is not the afterpeak bulkhead. (Note! see also Ref.). For ships with cofferdam, pump room and similar rooms & tanks not for the storage of cargo, forward of and/or possibly aft of the engine room, the bulkheads for these rooms are included here and form the boundaries of the engine area. - Bottom, bilge plates and inner bottom between above mentioned bulkheads. - Upper deck plus decks, platforms, tank tops and bulkheads etc., below the upper deck between the above bulkheads (bulkhead planes). - Shell between the above bulkheads up to the first open deck. - For vessels with poop and engine room aft, that part of the shell in the poop lying between the above bulkheads is included in the engine room area. - For vessels with long and high superstructure (e.g. passenger ships, car ships etc.), the shell in the engine room area up to the nearest butt of plates above the upper deck is included. If the next deck above upper deck is an open deck (and not deck house deck), the shell is included up to this deck. The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated: - Production costs. - License and patent fees. - Installation and adjustment. - Welding with chiselling and chamfer burning. - Testing and inspection (in workshops and during installation). For mounting and welding of parts (sections) with different group or subgroup numbers, the following rule is to be applied: - The work is to be charged to the part (section) which shall be mounted(following the section order). In the subgroups are included plates, stiffeners and strengtheners which follow the sections (shown on the section draw- ing). (Note! See also Ref.).
references: 304 Smaller Hatches, Grain Hatches, Manhole Covers
205 X-Ray and Ultrasonic Testing of Hull Parts

@value.label: Shell panels, separate shell plates
@value.definition: Separate shell plates and shell panels (i.e. shell sections with plates, stiffeners and strengtheners) in the engine area.
references: 262 Bottom Plugs, Sea Chests, Bilge Wells, Water Jet Intake

@value.label: Bottom, keel and bilge plates with stiffening
@value.definition: Bottom, keel and bilge plates (also loose fitting plates) in the engine area with stiffeners and strengtheners (Note! see also Ref.). Also included here are parts of frames and floors with knees, plus parts of adjoining bulkheads which are mounted together (drawn together) with the plates.
references: 414 Underwater Searching Equipment, ASDIC, Echo Sounder, Speed Log

@id: 223 Inner Bottom with Stiffening, Engine Foundations

@value.label: Inner bottom with stiffening, engine foundations
@value.definition: Inner bottom (i.e., double bottom and tank top) in the engine area with stiffeners and strengtheners. Also included here are parts of floors, frames, girders, knees and strengthening, e.g. foundations for engine, turbine etc., which are mounted together with the inner bottom plates, plus parts of sea chests, bilge wells and gutters which are integ- rated in the inner bottom. If bottom and keel plates are mounted on the inner bottom, these sections are included here.
references: 262 Bottom Plugs, Sea Chests, Bilge Wells, Water Jet Intake

@value.label: First deck with stiffening
@value.definition: Upper deck in the engine area with stiffeners and strengtheners. Included here are parts of plate frames, transverses, girders, stiffeners, bulkheads, pillars, shell, integrated gutters, etc., which are mounted together with the deck plates.
references: 525 Loose Floor Plates, Platforms and Ladders in Engine and Pump Rooms
267 Gutter Bars, Bulwark, Breakwaters, Gas Barriers

@id: 226 Decks, Platforms, Bulkheads, and Hull Tanks Below First Deck

@value.label: Decks, platforms, bulkheads, and hull tanks below first deck
@value.definition: Engine room sections between upper deck and inner bottom, excluding shell sections, and including: - Deck and platforms with pillars and parts of shell and bulkheads, plus transverses, stiffeners etc., mounted together with the decks/platforms. Forward and aft bulkhead in the engine area when this is not the afterpeak bulkhead, plus possible cofferdam or pump room bulkhead when this is included in the engine area (see the description under "Gen- eral" for group 22), with stiffeners, strengtheners and possible parts of shell, bulkheads and decks etc., mounted on the sections. - Bulkheads for casing, shafts, emergency exits, control room, testing room, toilet room, workshops etc. in the engine area, with stiffeners and strengtheners etc.

@value.label: Cargo area, hull small vessels
@value.definition: As the cargo area boundaries depend upon hull arrangement, this is described for the three main types of hull. The cargo area includes in this manner: 1. For ships with engine room aft: a. Bottom, keel, bilge and inner bottom between forward cargo hold or cargo tank bulkhead (bulkhead planes) - which can be collision bulkhead, pump room, cofferdam or deep tank bulkhead or other boundary bulkhead for hold or tank not for the storage of cargo – and aft cargo hold tank bulkhead - which can be forward engine room bulkhead, pump room bulkhead or similar as mentioned above (Note! The mentioned bulkheads are not included in group 23). b. Upper deck and decks, bulkheads (also for pump room between cargo holds or cargo tanks) and built-in tanks between the above c. bulkheads(bulkheads planes) under upper deck. d. Shell between the above mentioned bulkheads and up to the first open deck (see also point 3). 2. For ships with the engine room amidships or equivalent: a. The cargo area comprises everything mentioned under point 1, plus similar hull parts between aft engine room bulk- head and afterpeak bulkhead. If there is a pump room, cofferdam or equivalent aft of the aft engine room bulkhead and/or forward of the afterpeak bulkhead, these bulkheads (bulkhead planes) are taken as limitations for the cargo area in the same way as mentioned under point 1, first paragraph. 3. For ships with special superstructure decks and bulkheads: a. For ships with raised after deck, (i.e. a long afterbody deck above the upper deck) the deck with underlying bulk- heads is included. Excluded here are those parts that are included in the stern section and/or in the engine area. b. For ships with a long forecastle with cargo hatches, that part of the forecastle deck (including underlying bulkheads) which is  situated aft of the collision bulkhead or equivalent bulkhead, as mentioned under point 1., is included. c. For ships with long and high superstructure (e.g. passenger ships, car ships, or similar) the upper deck is usually the upper limitation for the cargo area. If the next deck above the upper deck is an open deck(not a deck house deck) the shell up to this deck is included. The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated:

@value.label: Shell panels, separate shell plates
@value.definition: Separate shell plates and shell panels (shell sections with plates, stiffeners and strengtheners) in the cargo area. Inner shell or double shell with stiffeners and strengtheners are also included here.
references: 264 Fender and Wear Bars, Ice Fins, Bilge Keels, Air Cushion Arr.

@id: 232 Bottom, Keel and Bilge Plates with Stiffening

@value.label: Bottom, keel and bilge plates with stiffening
@value.definition: Bottom, keel and bilge plates in the cargo area with stiffeners and strengtheners (Note! see also Ref.). Parts of frames and floors with knees, including parts of adjoining bulkheads mounted on the plates, are also included here.
references: 414 Underwater Searching Equipment, ASDIC, Echo Sounder, Speed Log
222 Bottom, Keel and Bilge Plates with Stiffening
264 Fender and Wear Bars, Ice Fins, Bilge Keels, Air Cushion Arr.
238 Bottom Side Tanks, etc. (Special Lower Constructions)

@value.label: Inner bottom with stiffening
@value.definition: Inner bottom (double bottom or tank top) in the cargo area with stiffeners and strengtheners. Parts of plate frames, floors transverses, knees and strengtheners, etc. which are mounted with the plates, plus parts of sea chests, drain wells and gutters which are integrated in the inner bottom, are also included here. When bottom and keel plates are mounted on the inner bottom, these sections are to be charged here.

@value.label: First deck with stiffening
@value.definition: Upper deck in the cargo area with stiffeners and strengtheers. Also included here are parts of plate frames, transverses, girders, stiffeners, bulkheads, pillars, shell, integrated gutters, etc., plus hatch coamings and coamings around domes and gas tanks, which are mounted together with the deck plates (see also Ref.). For ships with raised afterdeck or long forecastle deck (see under General, point 3), those parts of these decks which lie in the cargo area with similar hull parts as mentioned in the above paragraph, are included here.
references: 34 MASTS, DERRICK POSTS, RIGGING AND WINCHES FOR CARGO

@id: 235 Decks Below First Deck with Stiffening

@value.label: Decks below first deck with stiffening
@value.definition: Decks below upper deck in the cargo area with stiffeners and strengtheners. Also included here are parts of plate frames, transverses, girders, bulkheads, stiffeners, pillars, integrated gutters (ducts), etc. plus hatch coamings which are mounted with the deck plates (see also Ref.).
references: 528 Platforms, Ladders and Railing in Cargo Holds

267 Gutter Bars, Bulwark, Breakwaters, Gas Barriers

@value.label: Transverse bulkheads with stiffening
@value.definition: Transverse bulkheads below upper deck in the cargo area with stiffeners and strengtheners, plus possible base tanks and casings under deck for strengthening the bulkhead. Also included here are parts of stiffeners, transverses, decks, shell, etc., which are mounted with the bulkhead plates.
references: 238 Bottom Side Tanks, etc. (Special Lower Constructions)

@value.label: Longitudinal bulkheads with stiffening
@value.definition: Longitudinal bulkheads below main deck in the cargo area with stiffeners and strengtheners, plus possible base tanks and/or casings under deck for strengthening of bulkheads. Also included here are parts of stiffeners, transverses, decks, shell, etc.which are mounted with the bulkhead plates.
references: 239 Top Side Tanks, etc. (Special Upper Constructions)
313 Loose Bulkheads for Cargo, Grain Feeders

@id: 238 Bottom Side Tanks, etc. (Special Lower Constructions)

@value.label: Bottom side tanks, etc. (special lower constructions)
@value.definition: Special hull constructions in the lower part of cargo area comprising: - Bottom side tanks with parts of bottom, bilge, shell, bulkheads, etc., which are included in the tank sections. - Tunnel for propeller shaft (separate sections) for vessels with engine room amidships. - Hopper tanks (separate sections) for ore vessels. - Supports (foundations) for separate tanks for cargo (e.g. gas tanks)including intermediate layer, e.g., Azobe) with lock- ing bars and screws (Note! see also Ref.). Included here are plate constructions with stiffeners and strengtheners mounted with the plates.
references: 232 Bottom, Keel and Bilge Plates with Stiffening

@id: 239 Top Side Tanks, etc. (Special Upper Constructions)

@value.label: Top side tanks, etc. (special upper constructions)
@value.definition: Special hull constructions in upper part of the cargo area, comprising: - Top side tanks with parts of shell, decks, bulkheads, etc. integrated in the tank section. - Upper passageway formed as a top side tank. Included here are plate constructions with stiffeners and strengtheners which are mounted with the plates.
references: 252 Mast, Pump, Fan and Winch Houses, Companion Ways

@value.label: Forebody
@value.definition: The forebody includes: - Stem/bulb. - Forward cargo hold or cargo tank bulkhead - this can be collision bulkhead, cofferdam, pump room, deep tank bulkhead or other boundary bulkhead for hold/tank, not for the storage of cargo and bulkheads forward of this. - Upper deck plus decks, tops and bulkheads below upper deck forward of the above boundary bulkheads (bulkheads planes). - Shell and parts of bottom forward of the boundary bulkhead (bulkhead  plane) up to first open deck (e.g. forecastle deck). - Forecastle deck and bulkheads below the forecastle for vessels with ordinary short forecastle (even if this extends somewhat aft of the boundary bulkhead). - For vessels with long forecastle deck with cargo hatches, only that part of the forecastle deck with underlying bulk- heads which lies forward of the boundary bulkhead is included here. The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated: - Production costs. - License and patent fees. - Installation and adjustment. - Welding with chiselling and chamfer burning. - Testing and inspection (in workshops and during installation). For mounting and welding of parts (sections) with different group or subgroup numbers, the following rule is to be applied: - The work is to be charged to the part (section) which shall be mounted (following the section order).

@value.label: Shell panels, separate shell plates
@value.definition: Separate shell plates and shell panels (shell sections with plates, stiffeners and strengtheners) in the forebody.
references: 264 Fender and Wear Bars, Ice Fins, Bilge Keels, Air Cushion Arr.

@id: 243 Forecastle Decks and Bulkheads with Stiffening

@value.label: Forecastle decks and bulkheads with stiffening
@value.definition: Complete forecastle deck for vessels with ordinary short forecastle (even though the deck extends somewhat into the cargo area) plus bulkheads below the forecastle deck with stiffeners, pillars and strengtheners. For vessels with long forecastle deck with cargo hatches, only that part of the forecastle which lies forward of the bound- ary bulkhead mentioned under group 24 "General", e.g. the collision bulkhead, is included here. If the forecastle deck with bulkheads and shell above upper deck is made in one section, then the whole section is included here.
references: 304 Smaller Hatches, Grain Hatches, Manhole Covers
267 Gutter Bars, Bulwark, Breakwaters, Gas Barriers

references: 246 Bow and Stem Sections, Forebody Bulkheads
267 Gutter Bars, Bulwark, Breakwaters, Gas Barriers

@value.label: Decks and stringers below first deck with stiffening
@value.definition: Deck sections and stringers below upper deck in the forebody with stiffeners and strengtheners. Also included here are parts of plate frames, transverses, girders, stiffeners, bulkheads, pillars, shell, integrated gutters (ducts), etc., mounted with the plates.
references: 235 Decks Below First Deck with Stiffening
246 Bow and Stem Sections, Forebody Bulkheads
267 Gutter Bars, Bulwark, Breakwaters, Gas Barriers

@id: 246 Bow and Stem Sections, Forebody Bulkheads

@value.label: Bow and stem sections, forebody bulkheads
@value.definition: Stem sections and forebody bulkheads, including such as: - Forward cargo hold or cargo tank bulkhead - which can be collision bulkhead, cofferdam bulkhead, pump room bulk- head, deep tank bulkhead or other boundary bulkhead for hold or tank not for the storage of cargo - and bulkheads for- ward of this. - Chain locker with strainer plate, chain pipes built into the hull (Note! see also Ref.). - Stem with stiffening. - Parts of bottom stiffeners forward of the boundary bulkhead, e.g. collision bulkhead, excluding bulb (Note! see also Ref.). - Volume sections in the forebody other than the bulb section, e.g. cofferdam, pump room, deep tank, forepeak and bow sections (see also Ref.). Included here are plate constructions/sections with stiffeners and strengtheners, plus shell, deck and parts of the fore- castle which are mounted with the plates in the sections (Note! see also Ref.).
references: 264 Fender and Wear Bars, Ice Fins, Bilge Keels, Air Cushion Arr.
243 Forecastle Decks and Bulkheads with Stiffening
245 Decks and Stringers Below First Deck with Stiffening

@value.label: Deck houses and superstructures
@value.definition: The deck houses and superstructures include: - Decks, tops, sides and bulkheads above upper deck. Exempted from this are ordinary forecastle decks and raised after decks with bulkheads over the cargo area (Note! see also Ref.). For vessels with superstructure with several decks above the upper deck the superstructure sides start at the nearest plat- ing butt (seam) above upper deck. For vessels with one deck superstructure of the type poop, mid ship bridge on a "three-island" ship and similar, deck and bulkheads above upper deck are included in subgroup 253, while shell is included in the underlying hull areas (groups 21- 24). The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated: - Production costs. - License and patent fees. - Installation and adjustment. - Welding with chiselling and chamfer burning. - Testing and inspection (in workshops and during installation). For mounting and welding of parts (sections) with different group or subgroup numbers, the following rule is to be applied: - The work is to be charged to the part (section) which shall be mounted (following the section order). In the subgroups are included plates, stiffeners and strengtheners which follow the sections (Note! see also Ref.).
references: 267 Gutter Bars, Bulwark, Breakwaters, Gas Barriers

@value.label: Deck houses
@value.definition: Deck houses - i.e. houses whose sides are not natural extensions of the side shell - on the upper decks or weather decks which extend to the side of the ship. Included here are larger deck houses, complete, comprising: - Forward bulkhead and after bulkhead, including windshields (wind ducts, wind deflectors). - Deck house sides. - Internal bulkheads, including casing, shafts, etc. - House decks, bridge wings and tops with curtain plates, pillars and stiffeners. - Parts for wheelhouse of light alloy (e.g. aluminum), including packing, screws (also purchases). - Bolts, rubber etc. for elastic connection deck house/deck (also purchases). Included here are plate constructions with transverses, stiffeners, integrated gutters, etc. which are mounted with the plates.

@id: 252 Mast, Pump, Fan and Winch Houses, Companion Ways

@value.label: Mast, pump, fan and winch houses, companion ways
@value.definition: Smaller houses for special use, such as: - Mast house/winch house. - Staircase and ladder covers (companion ways). - Pump houses. - Fan houses. - Control room houses. - Compressor houses, etc. - Protective houses/trunks with coamings for gas tanks and similar (these can also serve as house for pump room, com- pressor room, control room, etc.). Included here are houses with sides, bulkheads, tops, etc., including stiffeners and strengtheners.
references: 267 Gutter Bars, Bulwark, Breakwaters, Gas Barriers

@value.label: Superstructures
@value.definition: Superstructures - i.e. structures on upper deck whose sides are a natural extension of the side shell - with similar items which are mentioned in subgroup 251. For vessels with large superstructures (e.g. passenger ships, car ferries, etc.), the superstructure decks start at the nearest plate seam above the upper deck. Also included here are decks and bulkheads in the poop (exclusive those parts integrated in the aft stern section), plus sim- ilar smaller one-deck superstructures, such as amidships house on "three-island" vessels.
references: 418 Radar, Signal, Observation and Antenna Masts

@value.label: Hull outfitting
@value.definition: This group comprises: - Equipment extending through the borders of the groups (areas) or   equipment which can be placed in different hull areas. - Equipment which is gathered in one group for practical reasons and which have little importance for the ship's strength structure. The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated: - Production costs. - License and patent fees. - Purchase of equipment. - Transportation costs (external). - Installation and adjustment. - Testing and inspection (in workshops and during installation). - Purchase of components etc. (not hull materials).

@value.definition: Following hull outfitting on the outside shell: - Bilge keels. - Fender bars and wear bars. - Ice fins, ice knives and grating (grid, screen) for main propellers (see also Ref.). - Spray plates in the bow (above waterline). - Aft ship fins.

@value.label: Funnels

@value.label: Loose/structural tanks
@value.definition: Loose tanks (not cargo tanks) that are not part of equipment they are servicing.

@value.label: Material protection, external
@value.definition: The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated: - All pre-treatment work, such as: o Scrubbing, brushing, scraping, beating and washing. o Pickling, etching and flame cleaning. o Sandblasting, etc. (Note! after processing). - Coating, such as: o Priming after processing (not shop priming, see Ref.), spackling and painting. - Other expenses, such as: o Purchases (materials and equipment). o Transport costs (external). o Testing and inspection. o Possible license and patent fees.
references: 122 Work Management, Fire Guard, Supervision, Watch Keeping
448 Nameplates/Marking on Machinery, Equipment, Pipes, Cables
203 Blasting, Shop-Priming, Rolling and Cleaning of Materials

@id: 271 Bottom, Boot Top, Rudder, Rudder Trunk

@value.label: Bottom, boot top, rudder, rudder trunk
@value.definition: Material protection by means of surface treatment such as painting etc. of the following: - External hull, including boot topping. - Stern and rudder trunk (box). - External rudder (see also Ref.). - Domes and other equipment on outer hull below top side. - Sea chests.
references: 278 External Cathodic Protection and Antifouling System
285 Ballast, SW and Stability Tanks, Cofferdams, Chain Lockers

@value.label: Top side
@value.definition: Material protection by means of surface treatment as painting etc. of the following:

@value.label: External decks
@value.definition: Material protection of weather decks by means of surface treatment such as painting etc. Included here is material protection of all external (open) decks, also deck house decks, together with gutters on these (see Ref.).
references: 274 Equipment on External Decks, Bulwark (Inboard Side)

@id: 274 Equipment on External Decks, Bulwark (Inboard Side)

@value.label: Equipment on external decks, bulwark (inboard side)
@value.definition: Material protection by means of surface treatment such as painting etc. of equipment on external decks, such as: - Mast, booms, derrick posts, derricks and ventilation pipes. - Gas tanks, external. - Lifeboat and life-saving equipment. - Deck machinery and other deck equipment. - Hatch covers and coamings, external. - Bulwark (inboard side), railings.

@value.label: Superstructures, deck houses, mast houses
@value.definition: Material protection by means of surface treatment like painting etc. of such as: - Superstructures. - Deck houses. - Mast houses, companion ways, pump houses, etc. - Forecastle and poop bulkheads. - Funnels.

@value.label: Galvanizing, nickel plating, metalizing
@value.definition: Galvanizing and other metalizing processes of deck equipment and internal components/piping.
references: 203 Blasting, Shop-Priming, Rolling and Cleaning of Materials

@value.label: Unassigned
@value.definition: This code is unassigned and available for use.

@id: 278 External Cathodic Protection and Antifouling System

@value.label: External cathodic protection and antifouling system
@value.definition: Cathodic protection of external hull, rudder and propeller. Included here are consumable anodes with fittings, and equipment for impressed current with anodes, reference cells, con- trolling unit, power unit and cables between these and anode shields (NB! see also Ref.).
references: 288 Internal Cathodic Protection and Antifouling System

@value.label: Unassigned
@value.definition: This code is unassigned and available for use.

@value.label: Material protection, internal
@value.definition: The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated: - All pre-treatment work, such as: o Scrubbing, brushing, scraping, beating and washing. o Pickling, etching and flame cleaning. o Sandblasting, etc. (Note! after processing). - Coating, such as: o Priming (not shop priming, see Ref.), spackling and painting. o Floatation, cementing, etc. - Other expenses, such as: o Purchases (materials and equipment). o Transport costs (external). o Testing and inspection. o Possible license and patent fees.
references: 203 Blasting, Shop-Priming, Rolling and Cleaning of Materials

@value.label: Accommodation spaces
@value.definition: Material protection of rooms in deck houses, living quarters and stores by means of surface treatment such as painting etc. Included is the protection of bulkheads, ship's sides, decks and underside of decks, as well as machinery, piping and other equipment in these rooms. Also included is the protection of partition bulkheads and ceilings, etc.
references: 522 Internal Deck Top Covering (Linoleum, Tiles, Parquet, etc.)

@value.label: Machinery spaces
@value.definition: Material protection by means of surface treatment such as painting etc. of such as: - Boiler and engine room. - Casing and funnel internal. - Pump rooms, fan rooms, compressor rooms, etc. - Steering gear compartment, room for stabilizers and other rooms with humidity and temperature conditions similar to the above rooms. - Tunnel for pipelines in engine area. Bow propeller room. Included here is the protection of such areas, equipment, etc. as mentioned in subgroup 281.
references: 285 Ballast, SW and Stability Tanks, Cofferdams, Chain Lockers

@value.label: Cargo holds
@value.definition: Material protection of cargo holds and space around cargo tanks (void space) by means of surface treatment such as paint- ing etc. Included here is also protection of piping, ladders, etc. in the holds, hatch covers and coamings (hold side), etc.
references: 274 Equipment on External Decks, Bulwark (Inboard Side)

@value.label: Cargo tanks
@value.definition: Material protection of cargo tanks by means of surface treatment such as painting or other types of coatings. Included here is also protection of piping, ladders, etc. in the tanks.
references: 288 Internal Cathodic Protection and Antifouling System

@id: 285 Ballast, SW and Stability Tanks, Cofferdams, Chain Lockers

@value.label: Ballast, sw and stability tanks, cofferdams, chain lockers
@value.definition: Material protection by means of surface treatment such as painting or other types of coatings on surfaces of such as:

@value.label: Fw and misc. tanks
@value.definition: Protection of fresh water tanks and other tanks (not naturally belonging to types mentioned in any other subgroup in group 28) by means of surface treatment such as painting etc. Included here is the protection of piping, ladders, etc. in the tanks.
references: 287 FO and LO Tanks Integrated in Hull
285 Ballast, SW and Stability Tanks, Cofferdams, Chain Lockers

@id: 287 FO and LO Tanks Integrated in Hull

@value.label: Fo and lo tanks integrated in hull
@value.definition: Protection of fuel oil, lube oil tanks and combined fuel and ballast tanks and slop tanks by means of surface treatment such as painting etc. Included here is the protection of piping, ladders, etc. in the tanks.
references: 285 Ballast, SW and Stability Tanks, Cofferdams, Chain Lockers

@id: 288 Internal Cathodic Protection and Antifouling System

@value.label: Internal cathodic protection and antifouling system
@value.definition: Cathodic protection of internal tanks by the same means as mentioned in subgroup 278.
references: 278 External Cathodic Protection and Antifouling System

@value.label: Loose tanks
@value.definition: Protection of loose tanks (no cargo tanks or integrated hull tanks) or tanks that they are part of equipment it is servicing.

@value.label: Misc. hull work (not standard)
@value.definition: This group includes miscellaneous hull work which the respective yard cannot refer to respective hull parts or sections and accordingly not charge to the respective subgroup in group 21 through 26.

@value.label: Marking
@value.definition: Marking for flame cutting, cutting, shearing etc. of hull materials.

@value.label: Flame cutting
@value.definition: Cutting of materials by flame cutters on cutting lines before welding.
references: 295 Burning, Chiseling and Grinding for Back Welds

@value.label: Cutting, shearing
@value.definition: Cutting, shearing, punching, etc. of hull materials before welding.

@value.label: Bending, flanging, rolling
@value.definition: Bending, flanging and rolling of hull material before welding.
references: 203 Blasting, Shop-Priming, Rolling and Cleaning of Materials

@id: 295 Burning, Chiseling and Grinding for Back Welds

@value.label: Burning, chiseling and grinding for back welds
@value.definition: Burning, chiselling, grinding, etc. for back welds on hull/hull sections.

@value.label: Unassigned
@value.definition: This code is unassigned and available for use.

@value.label: Unassigned
@value.definition: This code is unassigned and available for use.

The hatches include the equivalent to that stated under subgroup 303.

@id: 309 Common Hydraulic Oil System for Hatches/Ports

@value.label: Common hydraulic oil system for hatches/ports
@value.definition: Common hydraulic system for operating the following equipment: Hatches and/or ports included in more than one subgroup in group 30, together with possible cargo lifts (elevators), loose car decks and other equipment provided that the latter do not determine the hydraulic oil system's capacity requirement (NB! see also Ref.). The common hydraulic oil system includes such as: - Pumps with drive units, automation equipment etc. - Expansion and storage tanks with flanges, valves etc. (see also Ref.). - Cooling system in tanks or separate coolers. - Filling, sounding, drain and vent. pipes for the tanks etc. - Pipelines between above components and supply lines to hatches, ports etc. including return. - The system pipelines include all system components such as bends, T-pieces, flanges, brackets, expansion devices, pen- etration pieces, valves, filters, cleaning equipment, taps, spill trays etc.

@value.label: Loose decks and platforms for cargo, ramps
@value.definition: Decks and platforms with possible pontoons, for cargo, which are not part of the ship's hull structure (e.g. loose car decks), including such as: Plating, transverses, beams, supports etc. together with raising/lowering/moving arrangements (including separate machinery), securing arrangements, supports and equipment for stowing of decks etc. Also included here are boards for cargo shifting. Ramps for driving onboard or for stacking of cargo in connection with ports, together with ramps for driving between decks, including associated equipment stated above (note! see also Ref.).

Arrangement for grounding of the tanks. Included here are also loose auxiliary tanks for gas, which are used during cargo shifting and similar (see also Ref.).

@value.definition: Bulkheads in cargo holds which are not part of the ship's hull structure e.g. grain bulkheads, fish bulkheads, netting bulk- heads, partitions with plating, stiffeners, brackets, securing arrangement etc. Grain feeders, complete with securing arrangement.

@value.label: Hold battens and grating
@value.definition: Cargo hold battens and ceiling with bars, filling, deck covering, etc. Grating with securing arrangements in cargo holds.

Straps, chains with shackles, rigging screws and fittings for lashing. Air bags, netting, wire arrangement or similar for lashing cars, supports and other securing material. Bins, shelves, cases, hangers etc.

@value.label: Protection plates, covers, hatch tents and tarpaulins
@value.definition: Protection covers, plates (shields), etc. for pipes, cables and similar in cargo holds and cargo tanks and on weather decks, complete with securing arrangement, together with construction (strainer arrangement) over suction intakes for freeing of tank/grain ships. Tarpaulins for hatches and deck cargo, with lashing rope. Hatch tents with rigging, closing mechanism etc. Rain tents on gantry cranes, Seattle tent. Misc. covers (tarpaulins or similar) e.g. for life boats, ventilation pipes, winches etc. (Note! see also Ref.).

@value.label: Containers, pallets
@value.definition: Equipment delivered with the ship for storage of cargo, but which follows the cargo during loading/discharging, including such as: - Containers with associated machinery. - Pallets and cargo boards. - Fish crates. - Lighters (barges) for LASH ship. - Car platforms (which follow the cars).

@value.label: Standing rigging
@value.definition: Standing rigging for masts and derrick posts for cargo, including such as: - Wire, rope, chains and pipe stays. - Rigging details; rigging screws, shackles, etc. - Deck fittings. - Grounding (earthling) for rigging.
references: 374 Vent./Gas Freeing Systems for Tanks, Wind Sails with Equipment
311 Loose Decks and Platforms for Cargo, Ramps
418 Radar, Signal, Observation and Antenna Masts

@value.label: Running rigging
@value.definition: Running rigging for masts and derrick posts for cargo, including such as: - Wire, rope and chain (also for topping and slewing). - Rigging details; shackles, blocks, cargo hooks, swivels, etc. - Deck fittings. - Measuring and weighing equipment which is part of the running rigging. - Anti-swinging arrangement.
references: 311 Loose Decks and Platforms for Cargo, Ramps

@value.label: Hoisting winches
@value.definition: Hoisting winches for cargo, complete with steam, electrical or hydraulic machinery (separate machinery), heating ele- ments, fitted measuring and weighing equipment etc., together with own control and regulating equipment (Note! see also Ref.). Also included here are lifting winches that also can top and slew derrick booms.
references: 439 Common Hydr. Oil System for Anchoring/Mooring/Cargo Winches
316 Protection Plates, Covers, Hatch Tents and Tarpaulins

@id: 345047 Hydr. Oil Pumps with Drive Units

@value.label: Hydr. oil pumps with drive units
Manoeuvring winches for derrick booms
@value.definition: Manoeuvring winches (motor or manually driven) for cargo derrick booms, including such as: - Topping winches. - Slewing winches (guy and preventer winches). Complete winches with steam, electrical or hydraulic machinery (system) heating elements, etc. and separate control and regulating equipment (Note! see also Ref.).
references: 316 Protection Plates, Covers, Hatch Tents and Tarpaulins

@id: 346047 Hydr. Oil Pumps with Drive Units

@value.label: Hydr. oil pumps with drive units
Common plants for cargo winches
@value.definition: Common plants for cargo winches include equipment that serves (or is common for) both lifting and manoeuvring winches for cargo derricks, as for example: - Common control equipment (stationary or portable controllers, etc.). - Common regulation equipment (Ward-Leonard aggregate or similar, with associated equipment, etc.). - Common hydraulic oil system with pumps, expansion tanks, pipelines, etc., as described under subgroup 309, for cargo winches and possibly other equipment provided that the latter do not determine the hydr. Oil systems capacity require- ment (Note! see also Ref.). - Other common equipment for cargo winches.

@value.label: Loading/discharging systems for liquid cargo
@value.definition: The subgroups include, unless otherwise stated: - Production costs. - License and patent fees. - Purchases (materials and equipment). - Transport costs (external). - Installation and adjustment. - Testing and inspection (in workshops and during installation). The system in subgroups include all associated system components, such as: - Pipes with bends, T-pieces, brackets, expansion arrangements, penetration pieces, safety valves and other valves, fil- ters, insulation and sheathing, etc. (see also Ref.). - Local instruments and local regulating equipment (in the systems). - Local control (operating) equipment. - Protection covers (excluding weather decks and cargo holds). - Fitted flanges for connection to systems and associated components. - All auxiliary systems (connected systems) end at the intake flange on the system described in the subgroup.
references: 375 Blow-Off System from Safety Valves (Pressure/Vacuum Valves)
381 Sounding, Surveillance and Operating Equipment for Cargo Systems
326 Pneumatic Plants for Bulk Cargo Handling
448 Nameplates/Marking on Machinery, Equipment, Pipes, Cables
316 Protection Plates, Covers, Hatch Tents and Tarpaulins
361 Insulation and Sheathing of Cargo Holds/Tanks

@value.label: Loading/discharging pumps
@value.definition: Pumps with drive units, with possible couplings/gear, bulkhead/deck, penetrations etc. for loading/discharging of liquid cargo (oil, petroleum, chemicals, liquefied gas etc.). The pumps can be located in pump rooms, on deck or in the tanks (deep well pumps). Also included here are spray pumps for gas cargo. The subgroup also includes separate systems for equipment) for loading/discharging pumps or their drive units, such as: - Evacuation plant with vacuum pump (including drive unit), separation tank, etc. for loading/discharging pumps, so that these can also be used for stripping. - Lube oil system for loading/discharging pumps and for possible turbines and gears for these, complete with pipes, pumps with drive units, preheaters, valves, etc. - Hydraulic oil system for driving loading/discharging pumps complete with pumps, pipes, etc. (as described in subgroup 309). - Exhaust gas system and possible air supply system for gas turbines which drive loading/discharging pumps, complete with ducts, valves etc. - Here is also possibly included arrangement for filling (priming) of loading/discharging pumps with valves, nozzles, recir- culation tank etc. - Fuel system to gas turbines that drive loading/discharging pumps, complete with pipes, pumps with drive units, pre- heaters, valves etc. (see also Ref.). - Cooling and/or other separate system for loading/discharging pumps, complete with associated system components (see also Ref.). Even though loading/discharging pumps can also be used as ballast, tank washing and stripping pumps and for other sim- ilar functions, loading/discharging is considered to be their main function, and they come under this subgroup.
references: 381 Sounding, Surveillance and Operating Equipment for Cargo Systems
355 Loading/Discharging Systems for LPG/LNG in Gaseous Phase
883 Cable Trays and Installation on Deck and in Cargo Holds
715 LO System for Gas Gen., Common LO System for Other Machinery
75 STEAM, CONDENSATE AND FEED WATER SYSTEMS

@id: 351031 Hydr. Oil Pumps with Drive Units

@value.label: Hydr. oil pumps with drive units
Loading/discharging systems on deck
@value.definition: System on weather decks for loading/discharging of liquid cargo, including such as: - Pressure and filling pipes with safety and other valves, clamps, deck penetration pieces, insulation, etc. from land con- nection to pump room/tanks. - Loose loading/discharging hoses and adaptors for land connection with associated stowing equipment. - Branch lines from heat exchanger on deck, including this, for heating of cargo during loading/discharging (LPG etc.). Drainage trays for loading/discharging deck arrangement. Even though the loading/discharging piping on deck is also used for ballast, tank washing, stripping, inert gas, air during loading/discharging and as suction/pressure leads for cooling system (recondensation), etc., loading/discharging is con- sidered to be the main function, and the common piping comes under this subgroup.
references: 381 Sounding, Surveillance and Operating Equipment for Cargo Systems
355 Loading/Discharging Systems for LPG/LNG in Gaseous Phase
316 Protection Plates, Covers, Hatch Tents and Tarpaulins
38 AUX. SYSTEMS AND EQUIPMENT FOR CARGO

@id: 352040 Hydr. Power Pack for L/O Pumps

@value.label: Hydr. power pack for l/o pumps
Loading/discharging systems in pump rooms
@value.definition: Systems in pump rooms for loading/discharging of liquid cargo, including such as: - Suction and pressure pipes with air vessels, safety and other valves, clamps, bulkhead penetration pieces to tanks, insu- lation, etc. in pump rooms. - Branch lines from heat exchanger in pump rooms, including this, for heating cargo during loading/discharging (LPG etc.). Even though the loading/discharging piping is also used for tank washing, ballast, stripping, inert gas, air during load- ing/discharging and as suction/pressure pipes for cooling system (recondensation), etc. loading/discharging is considered to be the main function, and the common piping comes under this subgroup.
references: 381 Sounding, Surveillance and Operating Equipment for Cargo Systems
575 Ventilation/Air Conditioning Systems for Pump Rooms

@value.label: Loading/discharging systems in cargo tanks
@value.definition: Systems in tanks for loading/discharging of liquid cargo, including such as: - Piping with valves, strainers, clamps, bulkhead penetration pieces to other tanks etc. in the cargo area, together with drop valves  between cargo tanks. - Equipment for fine-distribution of cargo in the tanks e.g. spray pipes for LPG etc. (see also Ref.). Even though the loading/discharging piping or parts of it are also used for tank washing, ballast, stripping, inert gas, air dur- ing loading/discharging and as suction/pressure piping for cooling system (recondensation), etc. Loading/discharging is considered to be the main function, and the piping comes under this subgroup.
references: 381 Sounding, Surveillance and Operating Equipment for Cargo Systems
365 Indirect Cooling/Heating Systems, Cargo Oil Heating

@id: 355 Loading/Discharging Systems for LPG/LNG in Gaseous Phase

@value.label: Loading/discharging systems for lpg/lng in gaseous phase
@value.definition: The part of the loading/discharging systems that conveys gaseous cargo during normal loading/discharging operations, including such as: - Gas return pipes between tanks and shore connection with valves etc. - Pressure distribution pipes between domes and tank systems. - Special branch lines for discharging by means of compressed gas. - Loading/discharging compressor with drive unit (Note! see also Ref.). - Loose hoses and adaptors for shore connection with associated stowage equipment. Even though the loading/discharging piping or part of it is also used for e.g. inert gas, air during loading/discharging, vent- ilation and as suction/pressure pipes for cooling system (recondensation) loading/discharging is considered to be the main function, and the piping comes under this subgroup.
references: 376 Inert Gas Systems with Conditioning Plant
36 FREEZING, REFRIGERATING AND HEATING SYSTEMS FOR CARGO

@id: 355031 Hydr. Oil Pumps with Drive Units

@value.label: Hydr. oil pumps with drive units
Separate stripping systems
@value.definition: System for stripping cargo tanks of cargo remains, ballast, washing water etc. The stripping system includes such as: - Piping with valves, etc. in tanks, pump rooms, on deck and to bilge water separator (see also Ref.). - Pumps with drive units or ejectors with pipelines for drive fluid (from e.g. loading discharging pumps/system, fire pump/system or similar). - Separate pump with drive unit etc. for delivery of drive fluid to stripping ejectors. - Separator or piping system for connection to slop tanks (see also Ref.) If the stripping system and loading/discharging system have common piping, only the piping that is solely for the stripping function is to be charged this subgroup.
references: 262 Bottom Plugs, Sea Chests, Bilge Wells, Water Jet Intake
374 Vent./Gas Freeing Systems for Tanks, Wind Sails with Equipment

@value.label: Mud systems with pumps, piping
@value.definition: The subgroup relates to special ships that loads and transports mud systems in pump room for loading/discharging and hatches in ship's bottom for discharging of mud, including such as: - Suction and pressure pipe lines for mud with bulkhead penetration pieces, penetration pieces in ship's side with suction hoses. - Hatches in ship's bottom with mechanical and/or hydraulic opening and closing system with drive units for these.

@value.label: Submerged turret loading system (stl)
@value.definition: The subgroup is for revolving loading and discharging system that normally installed in the bottom, including the piping.

@id: 358025 Hydr. Pump Station with Pumps and Motors

@value.label: Hydr. pump station with pumps and motors
Bow loading system (bls)
@value.definition: Special loading and discharging system installed in the bow section, including the piping.
